GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN OFFICIALS.
div.p: Some interesting criticisms are passed on English officials in Egypt by the correspond. ent of the "Daily Telegraph” in Cairo, who sends the following article on the subject to the newspaper.
We have dealt with the subject in another column of to days issue.

It is impossible to live long in this country without becoming convinced that many of the reforms, in particular those of a mental or moral nature, are being wrongly applied. Instead of attempting to convince the Egyptian why some rule of conduct or mode of thought is inferior to, and more usefal than, those he at present follows, he is merely told he is wrong, and that he must alter--a course which merely confirms the Egyptian in his error, if error it be, and breeds a mistrust of reform and of the object of those who urge it.

No effort whatever is made by the younger Government officials to understand the people whom they are here to govern; they do not attempt to find out what circamstances and what ideals and inner feelings have conduced to forming the Egyptian's habit of thought and mode of life They do not pause to reflect that this has been reached after centuries of experience of religious, mental, and physical conditions of which the Englishman knows nothing. They do not seem to realise that in a philosophy thus arrived at there is much that is good and much that is more suitable to the native than that which has been the outcome of Westeru experience. The young official parti. cularly in the educational department, seems to have no idea of building on what he finds his great idea is to demolish. Hide-bound by this lack of experience of life and by the narrow, conventions of his University, he wishes to force the game outlook and the same ideals on a race totally unfitted for them by religion, training, tradition, and environment.

This is the attitude which has erected the barrier between the two races, a barrier which practically precludes all social intercourse; and which will, unless it is destroyed at once and for ever, become one of the most dangerous and effective weapons in the armoary of our political opponents. Set up in our arrogance, let us beware it is not demolished to our humiliation.

Another danger is the increasing frequency with which Egyptians are sent to study in England, dangerous because of the way they are treated on their return. While there they are treated in exactly the same manner as are all other members of the community among whom they are made much of, if the reverse they are shunned. But on the arrival of one of these Egyptians in his own country he finds he is treated in an entirely different manner, and in some cases even the very people who were his friends in England and his contemporaries "at the University draw away, and another is added to the enemies of the occupation, and, because of his education and his modern training, & more important one.

The Egyptian is often called ungrateful, and in many cases this is absolutely true. But is it not the manner of giving that is at fault ! It is against human nature to be unduly grateful for benefits that are flung to you.

Many of the reasons urged in defence of this racial barrier are undoubtedly true, chief among which are the different social position of women, the social conditions, and the ideas of right and wrong, the difference of which springs entirely from the difference in religion. Here, however, the young officials apt to forget that East is East and West is West, and imagines that East can be made into a sort of stucco imitation of the West ; he seldom attempts to discover from what these differences come, so that by & proper realisation of the sources from which they spring they may be, 'as far as possible, smoothed away. This latter course was the one followed by the earlier officials here, and is still to a very great extent by the higher ones. A less haughty and exclusive attitude must be adopted by the young gentleman who arrives here fresh from his University and finds himself suddenly placed in a position of considerable responsibility. Otherwise, the magnitude of our task here will be increased. The younger official has a very high ideal of duty, but he seems not to realise that human sympathy is an even more valuable asset in the equipment of those who have to govern, and that an attempt should be made to understand the outlook op life which others have.

It cannot be too strongly insisted on that this attitude of exclusiveness is one of the chief factors in the racial antagonism that is undoubtedly growing in Egypt. And it is the English who are most to blame, for he is a rigid adherent to small and unimportant conventions, whereas the East is lavish in its hospitality. How often is an advance made by the Egyptians in all good faith, and with all kindness treated as impertinence? Socially, the Mohamınecans are the most democratic People in the world, are not all Byual in the sight of Allah.

If the Egyptian is to absorb the good from our social and official system, and not only Western vices, we must help him to see their advantage by a closer intercourse, and not make them unpalatable in the giving. The barm done by the standers of the average young Englishman cannot be exaggerated; it to great extent counterbalances the benefits conferred by the labours and the genius of the great of our race.

div.head: A Sorcerer Forger
div.p: The Native Court at Alexandria has sentenced Sheikh Mohamed Alion Dreys, the well-known sorcerer of Alexandrin, to six years imprisonment with hard labour for having forged an official passport a few months ago when he left for France This Sheikh recently married a widow lady belonging to the wellknown Yagen family and daughter of the late Abbas Pasha Yagben. Only on last Wed ne day the marriage was annulled by the Mebkemah Shariah at Cairo on the petition of the lady's sons who considered their mother's rank too high to be the consort of a sorcerer.

div.head:
Sir Eldon Gorst.
THE KHARTOUM SPEECH.
div.p: (Gazette's special service.)

London, Thursday. The speech which Sir Eldon Gorst delivered at Khartoum is commented on with approval by the London newspapers The declaration of Sir Eldon reiterating the statement that there is to be no change in the line of policy inaugurated by Lord Cromer meets with universal approval here.

[It is remarkable that not a word has been permitted to leak out about this speech in the local Press and the greatest reserve is manifested in official circles in Cairo in reference to it, although there seems, judging from the above cable, to have been no hesitation in telegraphing its contents to London. Our Cairo correspondent called yesterday at the British Agency and at the Sudan Agency but at neither was it possible to obtain any information on the subject of the speech.

div.head: ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY SETTLEMENT.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service).

London, Thursday. It is announced that the Ethiopian railway question has been settled advantageously in French interests and it has been decided to construct a line from Djibouti to Adis Ababa, for which a new company has been formed. The work will be commenced as soon as possible.
LADY BRAMPTON'S ESTATE
(Gazette’s Special Service. )
London, Friday Lady Brampton's estate has been valued at £316,000. She has left £250,000 to charities.

There is universal regret here at the death of Dr. Gordon Morrell which took place very suddenly from heart disease. Dr. Morrell was well known at Assouan having spent many winters at the Cataraet Hotel and the deepest sympathy is felt for Mrs. Morell, who has already left on the first stage of her journey home to America
The Duke of Devonshire bas derived great benefit from the tonic air of Upper Egypt and will shortly go on to Wady Halfa on his dahabieh "Serapis ,'
The Germar Minister to Egypt, Count, Bernsdorff, has been staying a few days at the Cataract Hotel, and Prince and Princess Wendisebgratz are expected back next week.

Several people well known in the world of art and letters are sojourning here just now. Mr. Douglas Sladen, with his party which includes Miss Norma Lorrimer the well known author of several delightful books of travel, has arrived from Khartoum where he spent a week gathering materials with which to delight his readers in the near future. Miss Lorrimer is also writing a book on Egypt. She leaves for Luxor with Mr. and Mrs. Donglas Šladen tomorrow and will spend some weeks there.
Mr Talbot Kelly is expected at the Cataract Hotel very shortly.
In spite of the rumours of a bad season both Assonan and Luxor are unusually full for the time of year.
A small dance took place last evening at the Savoy Hotel and many visitors from the Cataract went over in the launch which was running to and from the island all the evening.

Among the dancers were Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke, the latter in a handsome black and white gown and Mrs Beamount who looked charming in white and silver. The garden at the Savoy, always delightful, is especially so on a starlight night, and the scene from the terrace, with the lights of the town and the steamers reflected in the water, was very beautiful as many of the dancers seemed to think who resorted thither.,

Suez, January 2. The remaining two cases of cholera at Moses' Wells ended fatally today.

div.head: CAIRO SCIENTIFIC SOCIETY.
div.p: At the meeting of this society yesterday a proposal was submitted for increasing the annual subscription to P.T. 120 to cover the cost of the publication of the proceedings of the society, which will be supplied to members.

Ever since the foundation of the society the aded has been felt of some public record of its work and the communications made at its meetings, and several times the proposal to publish the proceedings has been brought forward for discussion. On examination of these proposals it was found on former occasions that the cost of publication was so great that it could not be covered by any reasonable increase in the membership subscription.

But at the present moment a favourable opportunity presents itself of getting the proceedings published at a reasonable rate without involving the society in any financial responsibility in the matter beyond the payment of P.T 100 per annum for each member who receives the published proceedings.

In October 1906 some members of the Survey Department began the monthly issue of a small journal called "Survey Notes,"contain ing brief records of scientific work done in Egypt. Although only fifteen numbers of this journal have so far been publisbed it has already obtained wide recognition in scientific journals in England and Europe, and next year the articles appearing in it will be indexed in the "International Catalogue of Scientific Literature," so that its position as a recognised scientific journal can now be considered established. The publishing committee have already decided to widen the scope and alter the name of this journal, at the same time omitting personal notes of a purely departmental interest; and they hope to make it a journal in which workers in every branch of natural science in Egypt can publish brief reports on the progress of their own researches that may be of interest to their co-workers or to the general public, as well as resumes of scientific work relating to Egypt but published elsewhere.

The publishing committee of this journal. agree to publish the proceedings of the society up to twenty pages per month in consideration of payment of P.T. 120 In return for this the members of the Society would receive not only the report of the proceedings of the Society, but also a magazine containing original articles and reviews of scientific work of interest to all who live in Egypt.

The publishing committee of "survey notes” | consists of three members, and it the present proposal is adopted the society will nominate two additional members to this committee. It at any subsequent time the society agrees to accept the financial responsibility for the magazine, the nomination of all the editors will be imposed on the Society ; but for the present the majority of the editorial committee is constituted by those who bear the financial risk.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Officials
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph's" Strictures

The Cairo correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" Has condemned in no measured language, the system of treatment to which the Egyptians are subjected by the younger officials of the Ministry of Public Instruction in particular, and the English occupants in general. The article in question will be found on page 2 of today's issue. For much of what he writes there is certainly some justification, for instance when he deplores the fact that greater consideration of Eastern methods and Eastern manners is not accorded to Egyptian institution, for any attempt to change the ideas and prejudices of centuries in the narrow space of a single generation is one which must inevitably end in disaster. But this charge can after all be only preferred against very small number of the English Government officials in Egypt, and then only against the most youthful, while often in the case of these men we are inclined to doubt that things are in such a bad state as the "Telegraph's" correspondent would have us believe. It may be true that a few of the younger members of the Ministry of Public Instruction arrive in this country with a very exaggerated idea of their own importance, and with a very shallow estimate of the capabilities of the young Egyptian with whom they are called upon to deal, and this is the more unfortunate as the rising generation of Egypt is gaining a first impression perhaps of Englishman and his methods from contact with these gentlemen, by which they arrive at conclusions regarding them, which may be correct in as far as individuals are concerned, but are very far removed from being accurate estimates of the character of the English nation in general.

We believe instances such as the above to be, fortunately, very few and far between, and on the other hand it cannot be denied that large number of the officials, and more particularly the younger officials of this Ministry, devote a very much longer time to the personal supervision of the athletic training of their pupils, than they are called upon to do by the terms of their agreement.

Therefore, though as we have admitted, some of the points touched upon by our London contemporary are based upon undeniable fact, the article in its entirety is one which world be far more likely to convey a mistaken impression of the methods of the English Administration upon the minds of those to whom the actual facts are unfamiliar than to serve any good purpose.

We are told that the Egyptian nation is one of the most democratic in the world, all men are equal in the sight of Allah." If the opinions of the average Egyptian are democratic, he certainly contrives to bide them in

very effective manner, in bin home life the difference of rank may be over-looked, but in the street, the hotel, or indeed in all public places, then is no one more sensible to the Attention of the great than is your Egyptian Aspirant to social standing.

With regard to the treatment which student receives whilst at an English University, as compared to that which is accorded to him here in his own country, the correspondent, in admitting the difficulty which the Mohammedan manner of dealing with their women folk present, has struck the root of the matter. Social intercourse is impossible between the two nations, that is to say the fullness of the intercourse which exists between two European nations, as long as the feminine element is oppressed, and is consequently non existent on the part of one of the countries concerned.
HOTEL D'ANGLETERRE.

Whatever the prospects of the other hotels, the Angleterre has every cause to expect a prosperous season. All its rooms are occupied at the present, and are likely to remain so, for it is quite one of the most comfortable houses in all Cairo. Many of its visitors have taken up their quarters for the entire season, as in the case of Colonel and Mrs. Stuart Davidson, the Rey. R. Somers and Mrs. Somers, Mrs. Nisbet, the Missee Hyde Page and others. Senator Adamoli is also making a long stay with his wife and charming young daughters, the Duke Leopold Torlona is rejoining his son again in few days on his return from Italy. Don Ferdinand Osorio y Elola, the Spanish minister, and his wife are making the Angleterre their headquarters, and among the latest arrivals are Major and Mrs. Hickman, and Mrs. Moly neux and Miss Froom. Though the Angleterre is by way of being a quiet hotel, in comparison with the others, various forms of entertainment vary the proceedings dinner parties often be ing arranged during those evenings when the orchestra is in attendance. This management was the first to acquire the services of the "Imperial Pierrots" who have just arrived in Cairo, and their performance given in the dining hall on Wednesday night was very welcome innovation to the ordinary programme of evening amusements. This troupe is under the leadership of Mr. Harry Sellars, and its to pertoire consists of part songs and solos of a distinctly pleasing and popular variety. Ita members are gifted with good voices and their performances will fill a long felt want. They had a very good audience at their first appearance and made a distinct impression upon their hearers It is Mr. Sellars intention to appear at the other hotels in turn, and doubtless these pierrots will do much to add to the distractions of the season.

div.head:
Egyptian Politics
THE NATIONALIST PARTY.
div.p: There was a meeting of the Nationalist Party yesterday afternoon at Cairo to consider the question of opening a subscription for the Denishwai prisoners.

The health of Mustapha Pasba Kamel still leaves a great deal to be desired. On Wednesday evening at 9 o'clock he had a relapre and doctors had to be summoned in haste. On the advice of his medical advisers he has gone to Zeitoun.

The organ of Mustapha Pasha Kamelis excessively indignant at the interview with the Khedive, published in the "Daily Telegraph," a summary of which appeared in our special service telegram's yesterday.

The statesmanlike utterances of His Highness on the position of Egypt do not appear to please Kamel and the fact that the Khedive is stated to have deplored "the tendency of a few young Egyptians to self-advertisement, of their country by legitimate means" is taken as referring to Kamel and his fellows. The "Egyptian Standard" says :

"The insinuations regarding the National Party are so thinly veiled, and so similar to the hackneyed allegations of juvenility and agitation-mongering against men for the most part over thirty and in many cases over fifty years of age who are moreover distinguished for their pacific utterance that we cannot for a moment abuse H.H. the Khedive by believing that the reported interview is an accurate transcription of his utterances."

THE EGYPTIAN LIBERALS. Mohamed Bey Wahid, the leader of the Egyptian Liberal Party, bas issued a manifesto on the subject of the daplicity of the attitude of the National Party in regard to the pardon of the Denishwai prisoners. He especially stigmatizes the Nationalists for attributing the pardon entirely to their own efforts, instead of to the clemency of Great Britain.

div.head: THE SEMIRAMIS HOTEL
div.p: The management of the Semiramis Hotel is to be congratulated on the excellence of the dance which was held within its walls on New Year's night, and which was attended by the greater proportion of those whose presence always makes for success. The position of the Semiramis is altogether in its favour lying as it does in the most fashionable quarter of the town and halfway between Cairo and Ghezireh, and now that people are beginning to appreciate its many advantages and comforts it will surely take its place among the most popular and fashionable hotels in the place.

The ballroom is perhaps the most spacious as it is one of the most beautiful that we have at our disposal, and the parquet floor promises to be well nigh perfect after a little more use. The orchestra is of the very best, and the buffet and other arrangements all deserve the biggest praise. It is evident that the management has spared neither time nor trouble in providing its guests with entertainment of the most attractive quality, and it was gratifying to note on Wednesday evening that those present were appreciating to the full the efforts made on their behalf. Though never too crowded, there were plenty of people to make dancing enjoyable, while many others surveyed the animated scene from their comfortable chairs in the spacious hall. A great number of the officers of both the Egyptian Army and the Army of Occupation were present and among the others noticed during the evening were :-Colonel and Mrs. Parker, Mrs. de B. Carey with Princess Irene Duleep Singh and Miss Carey, Mrs. Maclean and Miss Barnes Lawrence, El Lewa Watson, Mrs. and Miss Devonshire, Mrs Carton de Wiart, Mr. and Mrs. Scott Dalgleish, Mr. and Mrs. Gillard, Mr. and Miss Alan Joseph, Mr. and Mrs. Appleton, Miss Coles, Dr. Tribe, Mrs. Moly neux and Miss Froom, Mus. Boyes, Miss Belmont, Miss Schulyer Ross, Mr. and Miss Rees, Mr. G H. Carey, Mr. Whitworth Jones, Mr. Hylands, Mr. Prioleau, Mr. Shakoor and Mr. Campbell.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: "IL TROVATORE."

Verdi's grand old favorite "Il Trovatore" attracted a large audience at the Zizinia Theatre last evening who were exceptionally demonstrative in their appreciation of the talent displayed by the various artistes concerned. The production on the whole was a good one. There were certain small defects, however, which we are confident will not be in evidence on the repetition of the opera. Among the principals special mention should be made of Signorina Bianca Besolü as Leonors who gave a conscientious interpretation of the character, several of ger numbers being admirably rendered ; also Signor Oreste Benedetti as the Count di Luna. His faithful performance of this rather trying character fully justifies us in our expectations of his abilities, expressed in our notice of "Faust."

* As Manrico, Signor Mario Gilion excelled himself and was on several occasions vociferously applauded. The famous aria which concludes the third act, "Di quella pira" had to be repeated thrice, the applause being uproarious. His rendering also of the favorite "Oh obe la morte ognora" met with great appreciation. The ballet "Zingaresce" thongh short was well executed and Signor Enza Longhi received a call to the footlights. The chorus was again excellent, the rendering of the hidden "Il Miserere" being especially commendable. Tonight "Loreley will be repeated and we understand that on Saturday will be staged "The Barber of Seville."

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: The Empress Eugénie, who has just arrived in Cairo will not make her first prolonged sojourn in this country under the present dispensation. Close upon forty years ago, in the November of 1869, when Paris was still " dancing on its volcano," and Sedan was in preparation, her Majesty, then with all the prestige of an Empress substantive, led the way in the Imperial yacht "Aigle” to the entrance of the Suez Canal. Of her following were the present Emperor of Austria, the then Crown Prince of Prussia and future German Emperor, Prince William of Orange, the English and Russian Ambassadors at "Constant” and a great company of British and foreign captains of commerce. Monsignor Bager, the Empress's almoner, conducted the Catholic religious ceremony, and thanked her Majesty for the deep interest she had displayed in the work. Do Lesseps had already acknowledged the obligation he was under to General Francis Rawdon Chesney, R. A., when he styled the first authority who pronounced the project feasible 'Tho Father of the Suer Conal.” The procession of forty ships, the Aigle leading throughout, completed the passage to the Red Sea, in some eight-and-forty hours, on November 19, 1869.
The Empress will pay a visit to Ceylon after leaving Egypt and will be the guest of Sir Thomas Lipton there.

The Duchess of Aosta, who has much bene." fitted in health since her stay at the Grand Hotel at Khartoum, left the capital of the Su. dan on New Year's Day for a voyage up the White Nile to Gondokoro. The Princess will return by British East Africa.
Prince and Princess Windischgratz are staying at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum.

The Earl of Sandwich is amongst the many well-known English people who are going abroad in search of sunshine, and is starting for Egypt next week. Lord Sandwich, who celebrated his sixty-eighth birthday in the summer, is apt to find the English winter somewhat trying, and intends to make a prolonged stay in Egypt, part of his time being spent in a journey up the Nile.
The "Pall Mall Gazette" says:

Sir John Aird, whose condition is said to be critical, should have many outside sympsthisers, and that not only in Egypt, where the barrage at Assouan is his great memorial, but, a good deal nearer home, at Berlin. That Berlin has the like of its present water supply is due, not to any German, but to the great British engineer, of whom it may indeed be said that his name has been writ, and pretty largely writ, in water. Otherwise, Paddington owes him its first Mayor; Art, a most shrewd and discriminating patron; and the House of Commons an Amphitryon it will long remember.

Lord Lanesborough, who goes out with the Duke of Connaught to Malta as his A.D.C., is one of the most popular men in the Guards and during the time he was in Cairo with the 3rd Battalion of the Coldstreams he made many friends. He is a very keen sportsman and a first rate shot. Lady Lanesborough is well known in Cairo society. As Miss Tombs she was one of the great beauties for several London seasons. Like her husband, she is immensely popular, and is certain to be much admired in Malta.

The Hon. Wyndham Baring, second son of Earl Cromer by his first marriage, who arrived in London from South America some time ago on leave from his banking duties out there, is not expected to leave England again nntil next March at soonest, as his lexve has been extended this time to nearly six months.

On Wednesday night Mr. Mitchell Innes, Under Secretary of State for Finance, gave a dinner party in one of the private dining rooms of the Savoy Hotel Cairo. Amongst the guests were, Mr. and Mrs. McKillop, Mr. and Mrs. Roussin, Mr. and Mrs. Dallid, Mr. Anthony, Mr. Trelawny, Mr. Blomfield, Mr. Barton, Mr. Storrs, Mr. Vaughan Wild, Mt. Etherington Smith, Mr. Weedon, Mr. Dowson, Mr. Greaves, and Mr. Barnett Stoart.

A Gas Explosion.
LONDON, January 2.

A gas explosion occurred at the Dyke Company (gunsmiths) in Aldermanbury followed by a fire which spread to the adjoining warehouses. The work girls escaped through the sky-lights. After the fire had been extinguished * body was found in the cartridge store. Two persons are missing.
(Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN LIQUIDATIONS
div.p: NEW YORK, January 2. Receivers have been appointed for the Chicago Milwaukee Electric Railway Company and allied concerns, the capital of which amounts to 80,000,000 dollars.
The Governor of New York State, in his annual message to the Legislature, recommends that whatever restrictions are advisable in the case of banks, should be equally applied to trust companies.
(Reuter)

div.p: LONDON, January 2. Anxiety is felt for the safety of the Canadian Pacific steamer "Mount Royal" which left Antwerp on 7th December for St. John (New Brunswick) with 230 passengers and 90 of a crew.

div.p: LYTTELTON, January 2. The British antarctic expedition under Lieutenant Shackleton left here yesterday Afternoon for the Antarctic.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE MOROCCAN SITUATION.
div.p: Paris, January 2. Admiral Philibert telegraphs that the French yesterday carried the stronghold of the Mediunna tribesmen. One Spahi was killed and three tirailleurs wounded. - (Reuter)
ORAN, January 2. The operations of General Lyautey against the Beni Spassen tribesmen are regarded as tarmidated. The troops engaged will be repatriated torthwith.
(Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH TRANSPORT ASHORE.
div.p: PARIS, January 2. The transport "Nive" is ashore on rocks five miles to the south of Casa Blanca. In addition to the crew there is a detachment of troops, and horses on board. The cruiser "De saix" has left Tangier to render assistance.
(Later). The "Nive" is a total loss. The troops have been landed.
(Reuter)

(Reuter)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the sex opinion pressed by our Correspondents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
EGYPT'S COTTON CROP.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.”

Dear Sir, In his report on the finances of the country, the Financial Adviser dwells on the fact that the cotton crop of the country has not increased in quantity for a number of years I think that the reason is to the found in the fact that all the lands in the northern and larger half of the Delta need frequent refresh ings with rice crops to wash out salts and strengthen the soil, and it is owing to the scarcity of water in summer that this beneficial rotation of rice and cotton can be resorted to on but a small fraction of the lands which need it. Until there is sufficient water to allow of a steady rotation of rice with cotton over two thirds of the area in the Delta, I think there will continue to be no advance in the quantity of cotton produced in Egypt. This rotation of rice with cotton is needed in a considerable part of the Fayoum and I think, even in the poorer soil in Upper Egypt. It would be interesting if those of your readers who have special knowledge on the subject would give their ideas to the public.
Yours faithfully
W. WILLCOCKS.
Cairo, December 30.
The remarks of the Financial Adviser on the cotton crop are as follows:

The year, as regards the yield of cotton, has been somewhat disappointing. Opening with brilliant results, final results have been unequal, and have not in many cases come up to expectation. The area under cotton was the largest on record, as the table below will show, but the total yield is unlikely to exceed that. of last year. The reasons for this are still somewhat obscure. The price of cotton has been satisfactory.
Areas under cotton (1898-1907) These are the declared areas, and are probably underestimated, but will serve for purposes of comparison.)
The figures after the years represent the area in feddan :

The following table of wheat imports and cotton exports during the last 24 years, illustrating the great decrease in the cultivation of cereals, may prove of interest. The first figures after the years represent the wheat imports in tons. The second figures represent the cotton exports in cantars:--
The wheat imports include flour and maize. In reference to the wheat imports in 1907, it is worth noting that 36,500 tong of maize were imported in 1906 against about 6,000 tons during 1907.
VOX ET PRÆTEREA NIHIL
To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,- A few days since I read what purported to be an in extenso translation of the inau. gural speech delivered by Mostafa Pasha Kamel at the meeting of some of the National political parties in Cairo. After reading it, I was mueb at a loss to find out what it meant, and, unless Mustafa has been very badly translated, it oe curred to me that it must have been after listening to some such a discourse that the old Romans invented the above well-known saying, The only thing tangible about the whole speech is the joy of Mustafa at meeting his friends and hearing the sound of his own voice, for when deprived of that element, all that remains accounts to about as much as the residue of a burst soap bubble.

I am told that in the original, this may have been a poetical effusion for which some licence is required, but even if that be the case I should like to tell the owner of all "Egyptian Standards" that if he wants poetry it may be used so as to convey some meaning ;-as applied to many of his political sayings, I would suggest something in this style:
"Write the characters in dust,
"Stamp them on the running stream,
"Print them on the moon's pale beam,
"And each evanescent letter,
"Shall be firmer, purer, better,
"And more permanent I ween,
"Than the things those letters mean,"
Now this is very good poetry, but it is not devoid of meaning, and I think your readers and those of the "Standards” will admit that it has some truth in it.

It may be that Mustafa, in his studies of the beautiful language in which the "Revue des deux Mondes" is written, has learnt that "La parole est donnée à l'homme pour déguiser sa pensée"; if so I can only say that he is an apt pupil.
Yours truly

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LIMITED.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Dear Sir, The chairman at the recent meeting having stated that the board had nothing they desired to hide, the following are a few points upon which further information might be forthcoming: -
In the balance sheet to the 31st March 1907 amongst the assets are the following:
Cash... LE. 4.200
Sandry Dobtors...... 38.000
Deposite with Government... 4144
Work in progress ..42.782
Assuming since that date that the branch profits have only been per annum as follows...
McClure & Dorling, Alex…..2.000
Mark G. Boyes & Co. ...3.000
Grant, Bondi & Chinn...7.000
should be assets, 30 Nov. 1907 DEDUCT Sundry Creditors,
31st March, including Bank overdraft and the purchase of businesses... ...

L.E. 84.251 exclusive of goodwill. land, buildings co. The company does not therefore look as though it should have been in such a terribly unhealthy condition as to require L.E. 54,000 written off as lost. The fact that Messrs Bondi. Pomeroli and Dorling (or the majority of the board) are interested in the businesses bought and résold is a reason why they cannot be too frank in giving their reasons for the steps proposed. It is incredible that the three businesses whilst under the same management which built them up should have so deteriorated in eight months that only a fraction of their cost can be obtained for them on a resale to the original proprietors. If it is a fact surely the board should say who is responsible for the extraordinary depreciation and make them responsible to the company.

It is said that Messrs Grant, Bondi and Chinn are to retain the profits made during the current year by their branch upon the company's capital and further that they are to be given free the company's sanitary branch in Alexandria as well as Mr. Pezzi's sanitary business in Cairo.

Anyway, apart from the question as to what the management have been doing during the past eight or nine months we want to know what they propose to do in the future. The idea of selling off profitable branches at a cheap rate to strengthen the head office strikes one as similar to a man cutting off his arms and legs to strengthen his head, but one also wonders what the head office is going to do as a building concern only, without any working capital, (apparently with still a part of the bank overdraft) a large and expensive board of directors, and a manager drawing over a thousand per annum. Has it any possibility of success? Does the present management when judged by its past exploits inspire any confideuce in its ability to pull the company through the mess into which they have landed it. The sharebolders in this concern appear to have been not at all well treated and it is to be hoped that they will accept the chair. man's offer to investigate the position before attending the next general meeting on the 8th prox.--Yours faithfully,

div.head: KHARTOUM TO-DAY
div.p: The City that is Gordon's Tomb

The city is generally considered to be very fortunate that possesses a river. But Khartoum crowns and Watches over three and these three amongst the greatest rivers of the world. From the troublesome magic of the Bar El Gazal and its sudd grass, from the hot confines of the Equator, the White Nile fetches its milky waters ; from the axure mountains of Abyssinia and througla the heat of the country's savage heart the Blue Nile flows to the Sudan Created in this fashion, and seeming to have rushed down south, rather than as it does, run northward, the Egyptian Nile is formed, and in return touches the city only to take its course again to the sea. Khartoom is built above this concourse of waters, but the windy currents have less interest for her than has the melancholy, waste whose historio miles make the Sadan famous for both defeat and victory. The desert bay already wrought famine and destruction, and if not quite so dangerously portentous now, the wilderness is nevertheless always sinister, and it is over this wild territory that Khartoum keeps vigilant guard.

There is a desolation, a mystery about it, and of all the mirage that cover the denert's face none gives the feeling of being more ephemeral than Khartoum does, poised, so it might seem, on the face of the African earth. Its history has been so vivid, its destruction so swift and complete, that even its present stolid foundations as yet scarcely seem really to pos. sess the soil. This is only a fancy. Khartoum, when we realise the force that has commanded it once again to take form, and planted its foundations deep in the minds of two nations, must possess a very real identity.

One enters the palace from the hot street into the Sirdar's cool ball running the palace's length. Besido cannon once used by Hicks Pasha against the Dervishes, retaken by them, and finally secured by Kitchener in 1898, stand Sudanese guards in unitorm of white linen, bright sashes round their waists, and the richest produot of their provinces-black ostrich plumes - nodding from their turbans. Along the stucco walls, eloquent ag are all trophies of warfare, range the arms and weapons taken from the Mabdi's and Khalifa's troops. Their primitive manufacture make these baroque decorations particulary-touching. They are of steel and brass and iron, of rotten wood, of pi. thy wood, worm-eaten and flimsy, pitiful and rude, at no time ever. fit weapons of defence against Remingtons and Winehesters and West tern flint and steel. Pitiful and rude, these weapons of defeat bristle and dangle, but all the menace they ever had is passed. In front of this savage dado used to wind the staircase which Gordon descended when he faced his companions, and where he stood to fall; and if these paltry weapons could not resist English and Egyptian firearms, they could at least massacre Gordon, and thus they awaken little sympathy as they range along the palace wall.

The fresh coolness of the corridor is broken by an arch, through which & vista opens into the wide, big outlook--the doorway upon such a garden as books of childhood all describe. The Sirdar's garden is like a dream come true: one looks with delight into the dense greenness, the feathery softness of vine, tangle, and shrub; into palm shadow and the glare of a tropica paradise. Acacias, mimosa, branches of feathery yellow; oleander and jasmine and tamarisk clus. ter, flower, and perfume; and triumpbant and abundant and all-pervading red roses colour the scene. The fragrance is augmented by the odour of the land itself: river winds, desert winds, the scent of musk and sandal enter by the great doorway and mount the staircase, climb up the ghostly stairway that seems to rise from the floor; and season after season the garden perfume, and the Sudan perfume sur. round the place like a fragrant cerement, or swing like a perpetual conser before Gordon's memory. From "Khartoum : A Winter Holiday," by Miss Marie Van Vorst in the January "Pall Mall Magazine."
HAZELL'S ANNUAL.

1908 is the twenty-third year of issue of this most indispensable publication It is the object of the Annual to put ready to the hand of the busy man as many as possible of the facts and figures which he is likely to need, during the coming year. To do this it is necessary both to keep a vigilant eye on the past, especially, but not entirely, on the past year; and to anticipate as intelligently and successfully as pos. sible what the course of events in the coming year maybe. The present volume is the resultant of the action of those two forces. Out of the past there has been taken all that seemed necessary either for the purposes of historical record, or for use by way of reference during 1908.

In the case of foreign countries and of British Dominions beyond the sens, it is particularly useful to have at hand a concise account of their political, military, naval, financial, and commercial condition and resources, and some record of the past year which may serve to make present events more intelligible. There is no publication, it is believed, which attempts to do this in the way that the Annual does.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: Football
Esna Barrage Works v. Government School
(From our own correspondent)
Esna, December 30.

On Saturday, 18th inst., a football match was played here on the ground of John Aird and Co., Esna, between the employees and the Government School, Esna, resulting in a win for the former ; the school team won the toss and play commenced at 3.80 sharp, At the sound of the whistle the ball was soon set in motion. The school team making a rapid dash for the home goal where they looked like scoring, only the goalkeeper being on his mettle just managed to clear, transferring the ball to midfield, when the home forward a after a few minutes hard play managed to net the first goal. On piay being resumed the ball was confined to one end of the field and after a bit of tricky play the home team managed to peg another notch just as the whistle blew, the score standing, Employees 2 School 0. The play being resumed the school having the wind with them and playing strong they tried hard to change the score and gave the home goalkeeper plenty to do, who saved well and cleared to midfield again where the for. wards were waiting, and having a clear field netted the third goal for the home team. The School tried hard to score but the defence was proof against all attacks and after the play being in midfield for sometime the school got away and were trying their hardest to score when the whistle blow, the score standing Employees 3 School 0 ; the school played well bat their opponents seemed too strong for them. A return match will be played at an early date, when probably they will reverse matters.
i H. M. S. "DIANA" v. R. A. M. C.

Teams representing the above met at Rasel-Tin on Saturday, December 28th. The ground was in good condition and as both teams were at full strength & good game was promised to the large crowd which assembled for the start. The teams turned out as follows.
H.M.S. "Diana”: Murphy, Boyd, Crowe, Davies, Thompson (Capt) and Maclean, Mellor, Jeffrey, Jarvey, Ellis, and Stokes.
H.M.S. "Diana”: Murphy, Boyd, Crowe, Davies, Thompson (Capt) and Maclean, Mellor, Jeffrey, Jarvey, Ellis, and Stokes."
RA.M.C. Speller, Tibbet, Sims, Welsh, Vid dler, Reynolds, Soody, Tripp, WcArthur, Skelly and Barnes.
Mr. Magee was referee. VH.M.S. "Diana" won the toss and hostilities were commenced by McArthur kicking off for the stripes before 500 spectators.

The Navy men then took up the running, Mellor, Jeffrey and Stokes, combining well got close to Speller, who saved at the expense of a corner which proved abortive, Touch was the order for some time until Tripp rushed away for the soldiers, gave to Skelly who went clean through the opposition and with a beauty opened the scoring for the home team. Not being disheartened by this reverse the Navy got away and Speller was treated to several hot shots, coming, however, through the ordeal with flying colours until a splendid combined movement by the Navy front rank ended in Ellis equalizing the score. Play was mostly in favour of the sailors and the home defence was kept busy. The R.A.M.C., pulling theniselves together, Tripp and Skelly perform ed wonders, their play reminded one of the oncé famous Bassett and Bloomer wing. Both teams were in fine fettle and the pace now was a cracker. A free kick for a foul throw in against the R.A.M.C., let the Navy away only for Mellor to spoil a splendid opportuity by getting offside. The visitors were now buckling to and Jarvey when well placed had po difficul. ty in giving his side the lead amidst cheers. Play ruled even froin this to the interval when the scores stood.
H.M.S. "Diana" 2 goals, R.A.M.C. I goal.

Play in the second half was opened by Jarvey and soon became brisk, the soldiers pressing for all they were worth. The Navy's defence was severely pressed but Soody wher in good position sent past Both teams were going great guns each goal being quickly visited in turn but all to no avail, as both custodians were in good form. Good play by Skelly gave Barnes a glorious opportunity. Taking the ball up he centred to McArthur who promptly popped the ball into the net making the scores equal. Play now became exceedingly keen the spectators urging their favorites to strive for the winning point. Midfield play followed. A free kick relieved matters and let the R A.M.C. away, but over excitement spoiled the attempt to score. The soldiers were now playing hard and the visitors goalkeeper Murphy, had to mind his P's. and Q's. Reynolds was very prominent in this half and some of his shots deserved more result than was fated for them. Mellor on the right for the Navy took the ball up and shot for goal. Speller saved three times in succes. sion before acknowledging defeat to the shot by Mellor, which was to win the match. Full time was approaching fast and play was car. ried to the visitors end in a last try for an equalising goal. Viddler missed by inches and just on the call of time Murphy saved the draw by a neat save. The game resulted.
H.M.S. "Diana” 3 goals. RA.M.C. 2 goals.
After the match the visitors from H.M.S. "Diana" were entertained to tea by the R.A.M.C.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The Duke of Connaught on taking up his duties at Malta an Commander in Chief of the Mediterranean garrisons, will have practically the staff that he had whilst holding the appointment of Inspector General to the Forces He and the Duchess will embark for Valetta about the 2nd January, leaving Marseilles on that date

The new appointment will tend to throw Gibraltar more into the shade, as it will be overshadowed by supreme entrol from Malta, but virtually the appointment will not interfere with things in Egypt For a considerable time the Army Council was undecided as to whether Malta or Cairo should be made the Duke's headquarters, but eventually the island garrison was chosen as the most central point. How this will work in wartime is another question.

An exchange has been sanctioned between Captain the Honourable A.C. Murray, 2nd Battalion 5th Ghurka Rifles, Indian Army, and Captain J.M.V. Stewart, 2nd Battalion King's Own Scottish Borderers. Captain Murray, who joined the Indian Staff Corps in 1899, and he holds the China medal for the Boxer campaign of 1900
Orders have been given that driver recruites for the Royal Field Artillery must be between 5 ft. 5 in. and 5 ft. 7 in. in height.
In the current issue of the Army List, Officers of the Militia, Yeomanry and Volunteers who have seen active service are so distinguished by crossed swords opposite their names.

It has been decided that from the commencement of the musketry training of the year 1908, the quantity of small arms ammunition to be expended by every trained cavalry and infantry soldier for practice and exercise under paragraph 1-5, Part 1, shall be limited to 250 rounds.

The new torpedo boat destroyer "Tartar" has just established a world's record in fast steaming. At her recent speed trials off Maplin, over the measured core she ran six consecutive trials at an average speed of 85.672 knots per hour, 35.363 knots per hour on the six hours' continuous steaming trial and on the measured mile she recorded a speed of 37 037 knots, or the equivalent of 44 miles per hour. Her builders are Messrs Thorneycroft, and the Admiralty stipulated only for 33 knots. The

Tartar," which is one of a flotilla of seven similar boats, measures 270 feet in length, with a beam of 26 feet, and a displacement of 795 tons. She is fitted with turbine driven engines of 14,500 h.p. supplied by oil fired water to be boilers. The armament consists of three 12 pounder quickfirers, and the usual torpedo equipment for the discharge of 18-inch torpedos, of which she will carry a senre, and the crew will consist of 60 of all ranks.
Next year's have maneuvers are to be held in the North Sen. Over 130 battleships, cruisers, and smaller ships will participate.

An idea of the naval strength concentrated in home waters may be gathered from the fact that between Christmas and the New Year some 80,000 men and marines of the Channel, Atlantic and Home Fleets will proceed on leave. The Channel Fleet has not been at home at this time of the year for a long period.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AND RAMLEH RAILWAY COMPANY, LIMITED.
div.p: EXERCICE 1906-1907.
Le rapport suivant du Conseil d'Administration a été lu à l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire des Actionnaires du Lundi 80 Décembre 1907.

Messieurs, Nous avons l'honneur de vons présenter les comptes de The Alexandria and Ramleh Railways Company Limited, du 1er Detobre 1906 | au 30 Septembre 1907. Les résultats en sont très satisfaisants.

1:--ACTIF Premier Etablissement. — Ce compte s'élevait au 30 Septembre 1906 a P.T. 15.816.688.4 et au 30 Septembre 1907 à P.T. 76.664.582.2 soit une augmentation de P.T. 847.898.8 Cette augmentation provient : 1. De l'abaissementet du déplacement de notre voie pas quite dn prolongementdo Bonlevard de Ramleh depuis la rue Khartoum, jusqu'à la tranchée de Hat-elNar. 2. De la construction d'un garage à la gare d'Alexandrie pour l'établissement du service gpécial entre Alexandrie et Ibrahimieh. 3. De l'achèvement du remplacemont des vieux rails

double champignon par des rails Vignole et de la clôture de la voie. 4. De l'achat de quatre voitures motrices et de quatre voitures remorquées, jugé indispensable par suite de l'augmentation du trafio. 5. De l'agrandissement des immeubles aux gares, de Sidi-Gaber et de Bacos, et divers travaux de construction complémentaires au dépôt de Moustapha Pacba. 6. De la construction de la ligne aérienne sur le prolongement du Boulevard de Ramleh et du prolongement de la ligne du Palais jusqu'au Victoria College en construction, à Siouf.
Magasin.-P.T. 1.443.748. 7. Ces chiffres représentent la valeur du matériel et des approvisionnements en magasi, suivant inventaire.
L. Steinschneider. - Compte achat Casino. P.T. 5.191.903. 9. Ce compte représente le solde du sur l'achat par lui fait do Casino San Stefano, capital et intérêts.
Société Aponymedes Tramways d'Alexandrie. - P.T. 2.300.014. 9 représentant les avances faites à cette Société en compte-courant.
Titres Compte Tiers -- P. T. 78.000 -- représentant la valeur nominale des titres qualificatifs des Administrateurs.
IL-PASSIF.
Emprunt obligations. - P. T. 1.699.000.Cé compte se trouve rédait cette année de | P.T. 117.000 par l'amortissement de 12 obligations au 31 Décembre 1906.

Créanciers divers P.T. 1.321.250,1. Ces chiffres sont représentés par les versements de l'Exploitation des Tramways de la Ville au 30 Septembre pour la somme de P.T. 1.807.812,6 et le solde par les créances de divers fournisseurs.
Conseil d'Administration. - Compte dépot P.T. 78.000. Coutre partie du compte "Titres compte tiers" à l'actif. COMPTE PROFITS ET PERTES

AU CREDIT Le solde reporté de l'Exercice précédent P. T. 28.060,2, Recettes générales P. T. 7.268 916,6, Intérêts, commissions et bénéfices divers P.T. 167.967,4 forment un total de P. T. 7.464,944,2.

. AU DEBIT Dépenses générales P. T. 4.179.634, 2. Le solde en bénéfice est donc de P.T. 3.285.310. D'après le contrat d'affermage intervenu entre notre Compagnie et la Société Anonyme des Tramways d'Alexandrie, le bénéfice Spécial qui vous revient sur l'exploitation du réseau de la Ville (Art. 3 du dit contrat) du 1er Janvier au 31 Décembre 1906 s'élève à la somme de P. T. 155.990,2. En ajoutant cette somme aux bénéfices précités, nong obtenons un solde total de bénéfice de P.T. 3.441.300,2, que nous vous proposons de répartir de la manière suivante : 1. Un dividende de 25% soit sb. 5 par action de Lstg. 1 nominale P.T. 2.681 250; 2. Au Fonds de Renouvellement P.T 500.000 ; 3. Gratification aux employés, P.T. 60,000; 4. Prévoyance pour accidents, trais judiciaires et risques en cours PT. 150.000 ; 5. Solde å reporter P. T. 50 050, 2; Total P. T. 3.441.300. 2.

Comme vous l'observerez dans la répartition des bénéfices, nons avons jugé utile de porter au Fonds de Renouvellement une somme de L.E. 5.000 au lieu de L. E. 4 000 comme l'an dernier, et cela en considération de l'augmentation de matériel roulant pendant l'exercice. Nous avons en outre prélevé, sur les bénéfices unesomme de L.E. 500 en prévision de risques éventuels, d'accidents et de procès en cours. Nous sommes heureux de dire que pendant l'exercice que nous venons de clôturer, le trafic n'a cessé de se développer, donnant un résultat des plus satisfaisants. En effet, les recettes ont atteint le chiffre de P.T. 7.268.916, 6, contre P.T. 6.423.077, 3, soit une augmentation de P.T. 815.839, 3. Les dépenses ont été de P. T. 4.79.634. 2, tandis que l'exercice passé elles étaient de P.T. 8.702.353, 5; elles n'ont donc augmenté que de P.T. 477.280. 7, laissant une augmentation des bénéfices d'Exploitation de PT. 368.558, 6. Le coefficient d'exploitation a été de 57,50 % contre 58,66 % l'année précédente.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Vendredi 8 Janvier.

On a ouvert ce matin très ferme et avec une Avance générale de la cote. Mais en cours de séance, comme cela arrive à la suite de toutes les poussées rapides, il s'est produit un ralentissement dans la demande et l'on a cloture onlme avec une certaine impression de lour deur. En faveur de la reprise on invoque la réduction de taux officiel de la Banque d'An. gleterre de 7 a 6 0/0, ce qui est un indice d'une détente monétaire, ainsi que la baisse du tanx privé à 50/0. Cependant, on ne doit pas perdre de vue que la réserve de la Banque a diminue A 85 5/8 0/0,contre 40 0/0 la semaine dernière D'autre part, il est probable qu'il passers en core quelque temps avant que nos banques locales se décident à réduire les taux écrasarts qu'elles prélèvent sur leur clientèle. Jusques-là la cberté de l'argent exercera son action sur notre marché. Il n'en est pas moins vrai que la baisse du taux d'escompte, si elle s'accentue en Europe, finira par déterminer ici one redno tion proportionnelle et une reprise générale, dès que surtout le taux sera descendu à un prix inférieur au rendement de la plupart des valenrs de premier ordre.

Pour en revenir à nos valeurs, la National Bank se relève de 19 13/16 à 20 1/4, la Ramleb ile 4 1/8 4 1/4, l'Alexandria Water de 10 1/4 à 10 3/8, la Daira de 12 3 4 à 12 7/8, les Lots Tores de 164 à 165, la Banque d'Athènes de 112 & 114, la Land Bank de 7 1/16 à 71/8, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 3 15/16 à 4 et la Banque d'Orient de 112 A 114.
L'obligation Crédit Foncier reprend égale. mont de 270 1/2 à 274 l'ancienne et de 250 12
251 1/4 la nouvelle.

Au contraire, la Delta Light réactionne de 9 1/2 A 9 13/32, les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie de 277 à 276, les Privilégiées Bière d'Alexandrie de 115 à 112; mais ou la baisse est vraiment sensible, c'est sur les Nun govich Hotels qui tombent de 14 1 2 à 12, en raison d'offres persistantes

Parmi les titres de moindre importance, les Markets progressent de 22/3 24/la Spinning de 7/32 à 1/4, les Cotton Mills de 1 à 1/3, la Salt and Soda de 13/- à 147, la Cassa di Sconto de 44 & 48 1/2, la Delta Land de 1 à 1 1/16, l'Investment de 5/16 & 11/32, les Estates de 11/32" 3/8, le Comptoir de 2 à 2 3/16, l'Aboukir de 28/- à 28/3, l'Allotment de 1 15/16 à 2 l'action et de 42 à 45 P.T. la tondateur, les Cotton Ginners de 1 3/16 à 1 1/4, les Ritz de 3/8 à 13/32, la Fanous de 1/8 à 3/16, la Levico de 9/32 à 5/16 et la Zariffa de 2 3/4 à 3.
L'Ordinary Khedivial Mail s'inscrit en baisse de 2 sbellings á 17/9 ex-coupon et la Port-Said Salt fléchit de 11 3 8 11/

Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changomont à signaler. Comme nous le disons au début, la tendance est un peu lourde, bien qu'on ait oloturé soutenu. Avec de bonnes nouvelles persistantes du dehors, l'amélioration pourrait toutefois se consolider .

Un correspondant nous demande si un sim ple actionnaire peut obliger une société Anonyme anglaise établie en Egypte et enregistrée suivant The Companies' Acts, à lui fournir une copie du bilan et du rapport des censeurs. Nous pouvons répondre à ce sujet que dans les débats sur le nouvean "Companies' Bill" on a introduit et adopté un article d'après lequel un actionnaire peut exiger une copie do bilan et du rapport des censeurs à un prix ne dé. passant pas six pence par millier de mots Quant au prétexte invoqué par certaines socié. tés d'éviter la concurrence commerciale, le Ministère estime que toute société anonyme établie sur des basés solides n'a rien à craindre d'une telle publicité et ne doit pas hésiter à foumir les renseignements en question un actionnaire qui lui a confié tout son avoir.

Nous extrayons du rapport du Conseil d'Ad. ministration de la "Nile Cold Storage Cy. Ltd" la à l'assemblée générale ordinaire qui a eu lieu le 14 écoulé, les renseignements suivants : La balance des comptes pour le présent exercice au 30 Juin 1907 qui comprenait une pé. riode de 18 mois, montre pour cette durée une perte de £ 5,535.10.7 contre Latg. 10,000 durant la période précédente qui s'étendait depuis le début des opérations de la compagnie au 31 Décembre 1905. Grace aux mesures prises par le Conseil d'Administration, les pertes ont diminué de mois en mois et récemment ont été remplacées par de légers bénéfices que le Conseil espère maintenir et augmenter considérable ment dans la suite. Les affaires du Caire et de Port-Said sont solidement établies et les administrateurs envisagent la possibilité d'étendre les opérations de la société à Alexandrie A la suite de la démission en Mai dernier, de Sir John Rogers de ses fonctions de président du Conseil d'administration, Mr. Dr. Herbert Milton a été élu président du Conseil. Mr. Astley P. Friend, ayant démissionné de directeur de la société a été nommé ingénieur-conseil. M. A. J. Tweedie, a été confirmé comme administrateur et M. Herbert Milton réélu en la même qualité. MM. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt ont été réélus comme censeurs.

Smyrna, 1st January 1908.
Sir,

We have the honour to inform you that we have transferred our carpet business to "The Oriental Carpet Manufacturers Limited" & that por firm as well as our branch offices of London, Paris, Cairo & Alexandria, cease to

exist from this date. The same signatures as hitherto remain valid till complete discharge & will be as follows "T.A. SPARTALI & Co in liquidation." We trust that the confidence reposed in us hitherto will be extended by you to the New Company and beg to remain.
Yours truly,
T.A SPARTALI & O The Oriental Carpet Manufacturers Limited.

TO OUR VISITORS.

The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompaning description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.

div.p: The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 14 Janvier 1908.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
